Your goal is to checkmate your opponent's king using tactical and strategic play.

Here are examples of good chess decision-making:

Example 1: Opening with '[e2e4]' controls the center and develops pieces quickly. This is better than '[h2h3]' which wastes time on the edge.

Example 2: When your king is in danger, prioritize safety. Castling with '[e1g1]' moves your king to safety behind pawns.

Example 3: Look for tactical opportunities. If opponent's queen is undefended, move your knight with '[g1f3]' to attack it and gain material advantage.

Make your moves in UCI format enclosed in square brackets (e.g., [e2e4]).

Invalid moves include same-square moves (e.g. [e8e8]) and moves to squares you cannot reach. Always double-check your move format and ensure the move is legal in the current position.
